attributes.comment:
I'm worried the way this impacts patient care regarding the provider directory. Clinical definitions are meaningless in this regard. What matters is how the patient perceives their provider. Someone's inner identity has no bearing on how they are perceived by others.

In a healthcare setting, a patient not sharing critical details with their provider or walking out of an appointment because they feel uncomfortable that their perception does not line up with their expectation is a very negative outcome.

If I want a man as a provider, I want someone that is indistinguishable from a male. Apart from edge cases, the easiest way is to let the patient know if their provider is XX or XY.

This is especially true considering that the medicare provider directory is used by older Americans - A man/male or woman/female is simply what they perceive them to be, their identity does not matter.

attributes.title: Comment on CMS-2022-0163-0001
